channel.title: Im stuck
channel.description: Well you see im trying to create a GUI that when closed or a button is pressed returns something so lets say, to open the GUI you run class.openGUI(); and the method openGUI() returns an object, like in JOptionPane... but its not working, i tried putting some Threads to run the GUI and a while loop to wait till its closed but it does not work, i tried studying the JOptionPane class but i cant really get anything form it, so any 1 wanna help?

item.title: Im stuck
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“super_, post:23, topic:182660”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=244330.msg2070406#msg2070406 date=1203668193]

Taharok is the master at reading retarded posts in which make no sense.

!!

I guess my year of incompetent moderating on moparscape has finally paid off.

I dont use the asterisk ever when I am importing unless I am using the entire package. I don’t know why, but I just have gotten used to doing that. Plus, the java source files don’t use the asterisk either (from what I have seen at least…)

incompetent life moar like

fuck off arrogant faggot
[/quote]

ONE TO TALK LOL[/quote]

Did I deny my being arrogant? Quite to the contrary actually. I am arrogant and a hypocrite. As are you.

item.title: Im stuck
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

nueb35:

oh and also people usually don’t use * because their IDE puts the imports directly

I set eclipse to use a * if I import from the same package twice. It speeds things up as I generally use a lot of things from the same package. There are no conflicts because if I try and import another duplicate class it asks nicely which one I want and makes a specific import. I have no knowledge of what happens in the code folded import block, neither to I want nor need to.

Read full topic

item.title: Im stuck
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“supamagier, post:10, topic:182660”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=244330.msg2064428#msg2064428 date=1203408874]

Well you see im trying to create a GUI that when closed or a button is pressed returns something so lets say, to open the GUI you run class.openGUI(); and the method openGUI() returns an object, like in JOptionPane… but its not working, i tried putting some Threads to run the GUI and a while loop to wait till its closed but it does not work, i tried studying the JOptionPane class but i cant really get anything form it, so any 1 wanna help?

How about this:

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.BoxLayout;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import java.awt.event.WindowAdapter;
import java.awt.event.ActionListener;
import java.awt.event.WindowEvent;
import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

public class GUI extends JFrame implements ActionListener {
	public JFrame returnedInstance;

	public GUI() {
		super("A random gui for nueb35");
		final GUI gui = this;
		this.addWindowListener(new WindowAdapter() {
			public void windowClosing(WindowEvent e) {
				returnedInstance = gui;
			}
		});
		JPanel main = new JPanel();
		BoxLayout layout = new BoxLayout(main, BoxLayout.X_AXIS);
		main.setLayout(layout);
		JButton button1 = new JButton("Push me");
		JButton button2 = new JButton("No, push me!");
		button1.addActionListener(this);
		button2.addActionListener(this);
		main.add(button1);
		main.add(button2);
		this.add(main);
	}

	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		returnInstance = this;
	}

	public static void main(String args[]) {
		final GUI gui = new GUI();
		gui.pack();
		gui.setVisible(true);
		new Thread(new Runnable() {
			public void run() {
				while (returnedInstance == null) ;
				System.out.println("Our window is set: " + gui.returnedInstance.toString());
			}
		}).start();
	}
}


[/quote]

import javax.swing.JFrame; import javax.swing.BoxLayout; import javax.swing.JPanel; import javax.swing.JButton; import java.awt.event.WindowAdapter; import java.awt.event.ActionListener; import java.awt.event.WindowEvent; import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

just use

import javax.swing.*; import java.awt.event.*;
?[/quote]

now that sounds form moparscape :0

you see when you import * you import useless things which you will not use and this takes up memory

Read full topic

[/quote]

How about this:

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.BoxLayout;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import java.awt.event.WindowAdapter;
import java.awt.event.ActionListener;
import java.awt.event.WindowEvent;
import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

public class GUI extends JFrame implements ActionListener {
	public JFrame returnedInstance;

	public GUI() {
		super("A random gui for nueb35");
		final GUI gui = this;
		this.addWindowListener(new WindowAdapter() {
			public void windowClosing(WindowEvent e) {
				returnedInstance = gui;
			}
		});
		JPanel main = new JPanel();
		BoxLayout layout = new BoxLayout(main, BoxLayout.X_AXIS);
		main.setLayout(layout);
		JButton button1 = new JButton("Push me");
		JButton button2 = new JButton("No, push me!");
		button1.addActionListener(this);
		button2.addActionListener(this);
		main.add(button1);
		main.add(button2);
		this.add(main);
	}

	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		returnInstance = this;
	}

	public static void main(String args[]) {
		final GUI gui = new GUI();
		gui.pack();
		gui.setVisible(true);
		new Thread(new Runnable() {
			public void run() {
				while (returnedInstance == null) ;
				System.out.println("Our window is set: " + gui.returnedInstance.toString());
			}
		}).start();
	}
}

:P[/quote]

import javax.swing.JFrame; import javax.swing.BoxLayout; import javax.swing.JPanel; import javax.swing.JButton; import java.awt.event.WindowAdapter; import java.awt.event.ActionListener; import java.awt.event.WindowEvent; import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

item.title: Im stuck
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

nueb35:

Well you see im trying to create a GUI that when closed or a button is pressed returns something so lets say, to open the GUI you run class.openGUI(); and the method openGUI() returns an object, like in JOptionPane… but its not working, i tried putting some Threads to run the GUI and a while loop to wait till its closed but it does not work, i tried studying the JOptionPane class but i cant really get anything form it, so any 1 wanna help?

How about this:

import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.BoxLayout;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.JButton;
import java.awt.event.WindowAdapter;
import java.awt.event.ActionListener;
import java.awt.event.WindowEvent;
import java.awt.event.ActionEvent;

public class GUI extends JFrame implements ActionListener {
	public JFrame returnedInstance;

	public GUI() {
		super("A random gui for nueb35");
		final GUI gui = this;
		this.addWindowListener(new WindowAdapter() {
			public void windowClosing(WindowEvent e) {
				returnedInstance = gui;
			}
		});
		JPanel main = new JPanel();
		BoxLayout layout = new BoxLayout(main, BoxLayout.X_AXIS);
		main.setLayout(layout);
		JButton button1 = new JButton("Push me");
		JButton button2 = new JButton("No, push me!");
		button1.addActionListener(this);
		button2.addActionListener(this);
		main.add(button1);
		main.add(button2);
		this.add(main);
	}

	public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
		returnInstance = this;
	}

	public static void main(String args[]) {
		final GUI gui = new GUI();
		gui.pack();
		gui.setVisible(true);
		new Thread(new Runnable() {
			public void run() {
				while (returnedInstance == null) ;
				System.out.println("Our window is set: " + gui.returnedInstance.toString());
			}
		}).start();
	}
}
